Award.AwardTitle: Functions of a novel noncoding RNA family

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to understand how a new family of molecules controls how genes are turned on or off. Unlike most known gene regulators, which are proteins, these regulators are chains of ribonucleotides called noncoding RNAs. These particular ncRNAs were discovered in the model organism C. elegans in earlier work on this project, which also suggested they have functions during C. elegans development. So, this study will reveal new insights into regulatory pathways that are critical to animal development and gene regulation. In addition, the project will develop new methods to detect and count millions of RNA molecules from small amounts of material. These methods could have broad applications including in medical diagnosis, new environmental survey methods, or forensics investigations. This project will also provide scientific training of a graduate student, who will conduct this research as part of their PhD thesis, and will serve as the basis of a research training program for undergraduate students interested in science or science-related careers.

Noncoding RNAs (ncRNAs) are rapidly emerging as surprisingly prominent and diverse regulators. However, functions of most ncRNAs are a mystery. Preliminary studies for this project discovered a family of novel ncRNAs that bind Sm rings, relatives of ancient protein complexes found in all domains of life. In eukaryotes, Sm rings are core components of snRNA complexes that catalyze mRNA splicing. However, several studies suggest that Sm rings have a variety of other poorly understood functions. Collectively, these findings suggest that multiple Sm-bound ncRNAs control unknown RNA targets, thereby regulating a variety of processes. This project will explore this idea using the nematode C. elegans as a model system. Targeted gene disruption will be combined with unique high throughput RNA sequencing strategies and established assays to determine how Sm ncRNA mutations alter RNA profiles and other biological functions. Transgene manipulations will test emergent models for how Sm ncRNAs control RNA targets in vivo. This project will reveal functions of novel ncRNAs, which represent a new, poorly understood paradigm of genetic control. Results may transform ideas for the functions of Sm family rings and their ncRNA partners. In addition, this project will help develop new genome scale methods and bioinformatic tools that will have broad applicability to the many other families of ncRNAs emerging from genomes throughout phylogeny.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Revolutionary methods have revealed thousands of previously unknown genes in many species, from single cell organisms to humans. These genes make noncoding RNAs (ncRNAs) that do not produce proteins but may instead be RNA-based regulators. However, the functions of most ncRNAs are a mystery. Using the nematode worm C. elegans, this project discovered thirty novel ncRNAs of the Sm family, a large class of ncRNAs found throughout all of life's domains. Surprisingly, all but one of these new Sm ncRNAs can not easily be found in other nematode species (i.e. non-conserved). However, careful analysis revealed that other species do have very similar ncRNA genes; they contain short, conserved elements embedded within rapidly evolving RNA sequence suggesting they have unique functions (Fig. 1). Indeed, mutations of four Sm ncRNAs impaired development after young worms were starved and then fed. In free living nematodes, post-embryonic development will be stopped if there is no food and will resume when food becomes available. The mechanisms that brake and re-start development are related to nutrition control systems in humans, which include insulin pathways. Therefore, some novel Sm ncRNAs promote this nutrition-activated growth and development.

While exploring how new Sm ncRNAs work, one unique ncRNA was found to drive the final step in formation of histone mRNAs, which produce proteins that package DNA in chromosomes. This ncRNA functions like human U7 ncRNA but is not related to U7 by sequence. Results revealed that another unknown mechanism can also mediate the same histone processing step such that the U7-like gene is not essential. This allowed investigation of other potential functions. Surprisingly, U7-like ncRNA also suppresses virus-derived retrotransposon elements, invaders of the genome that can be detrimental. Interestingly, the fast-evolving Sm ncRNAs act by different mechanisms but also contribute to repression of retrotransposon genes and a different transposon type. Somehow, these different ncRNAs converge on conserved pathways to influence post-embryonic development. Interestingly, these same transposon elements are also silenced by small ncRNAs (called siRNAs and piRNAs), relatives of which are found from plants to humans. Retrotransposons and other transposon elements are common in many genomes including human. Therefore, novel Sm ncRNAs may control conserved small RNA pathways that defend against invasive genetic elements, but other possibilities remain.

Taken together, this study suggests that fast-evolving Sm ncRNAs are modifiers; they influence pathways of defense and developmental control that are sensitive to environments. Noncoding RNA genes may provide flexible platforms for adaptations of organisms to changing environments, invasive elements like viruses, or other forms of stress. Novel Sm family ncRNAs discovered by this project may represent a previously unknown group of such adapters.

This project's outcomes have several broader impacts. Scientifically, this work supports a new idea that ncRNA genes may key substrates for species variation and adaptation. Gene sequence conservation has long been a driver of experimental biology, but this work argues for new approaches to discover and understand modifier genes that remain hidden in our genomes. More broadly, novel ncRNAs could lead to new tools to manipulate genes important to human, plant, or animal disease. In addition, the project also developed new methods of RNA sequencing that could have broad applications, including diverse new investigations, environmental surveys, or forensics. Towards broader education goals, the project served as critical training of two post-undergraduate students and first lab experiences for two undergraduate female students, three of whom are in or plan to enter PhD science programs.
